column1: It seemed to Babette a very long time to wait; for the leaves upon the trees were tender yet
column2: and the figs were like little hard
column3: green marbles. But warm rains came along and plenty of strong sunshine
column4: and though Maman-Naiaine was as patient as the statue of la Madone
column5: and Babette as restless as a hummingbird
column6: the first thing they both knew it was hot summertime. Every day Babette danced out to where the fig-trees were in a long line against the fence. She walked slowly beneath them
column8: spreading branches. But each time she came disconsolate away again. What she saw there finally was something that made her sing and dance the whole long day.When Maman-Nainaine sat down in her stately way to breakfast
column10: her muslin cap standing like an aureole about her white
column12: Babette approached. She bore a dainty porcelain platter
column13: which she set down before her godmother. It contained a dozen purple figs
